Equations for lines using polar coordinates are not as nice as equations in rectangular coordinates. However, if we are working in polar coordinates, we still need a way to express lines.

The easiest way to express lines in polar coordinates is the special case of lines through the pole. All the points on a line through the pole can be expressed with the same \(\theta\)-coordinate \(\theta_1.\) Thus the equation for such a line can be expressed as \(\theta=\theta_1.\) For example, all the points on with a \(\theta\)-coordinate of \(30^\circ\) can be expressed as the equation \(\theta=30^\circ.\)

Vertical lines have the form \(x=a\) in rectangular coordinates. The easiest way to get an equation for a vertical line using polar coordinates is to use our conversion equation \(x=r\cos\theta\). Substituting this into \(x=a\), we get \(r\cos\theta = a.\) We can manipulate this to \(r=\frac{a}{\cos\theta}\) or to \(r=a\sec\theta\) if we would prefer the equation expressed as a function of \(\theta.\)

Horizontal lines have the form \(y=b\) in rectangular coordinates. The easiest way to get an equation for a horizontal line using polar coordinates is to use our conversion equation \(y=r\sin\theta\). Substituting this into \(y=b\), we get \(r\sin\theta = b.\) We can manipulate this to \(r=\frac{b}{\sin\theta}\) or to \(r=a\csc\theta\) if we would prefer the equation expressed as a function of \(\theta.\)

Finally, if we exclude lines through the pole/origin, vertical lines, and horizontal lines, we are left with oblique lines that do not go through the origin. These can be expressed in slope-intercept form as \(y=mx+b\), where \(b\) is not zero. Using our conversion equations, we get \(r\sin\theta=m(r\cos\theta)+b.\) Solving for \(r\), we get \(r=\frac{b}{\sin\theta-m\cos\theta}.\)

Alternatively, we could start with general form \(Ax+By+C=0\) and have a single form for oblique, vertical, and horizontal lines that don't go through the pole (\(C\neq 0\)). Substituting, we get \(A(r\cos\theta)+B(r\sin\theta)+C=0.\). Solving for \(r\), we get \(r=\frac{-C}{A\cos\theta+B\sin\theta}.\) Notice that this form can also work with vertical or horizontal lines so long as they don't go through the origin/pole.

Perhaps the best way to give a general line not through the pole is to use intercept form: \(\frac{x}{a}+\frac{y}{b}=1\). Substitute to get \(\frac{r\cos\theta}{a}+\frac{r\sin\theta}{b}=1.\) Multiply both sides by \(ab\) to eliminate fractions: \(rb\cos\theta+ra\sin\theta=ab.\) Factor out \(r\) and then divide to solve for \(r\): \(r=\frac{ab}{b\cos\theta+a\sin\theta}.\)

You can experiment with this formula in the following desmos graph (click on edit graph on desmos to open in a new tab). Try changing the \(x\)-intercept using the slider for \(a\) and the \(y\)-intercept using the slider for \(b.\)

Summary:

  • lines through the pole: a line through the pole contains all the points who have a given angle \(\theta_0\) for their \(\theta\)-coordinate. These lines have an equation of the form \(\theta=\theta_0\).
  • lines not through the pole: if a line does not go through the pole, it is easiest to describe it in rectangular coordinates and then convert it to polar. There are three main types:
    • vertical lines \(r=a\sec\theta\): use the vertical line equation \(x=a\) and \(x=r\cos\theta\) to get \(r=a\sec\theta\).
    • horizontal lines \(r=b\csc\theta\): use the horizontal line equation \(y=b\) and \(y=r\sin\theta\) to get \(r=b\csc\theta\).
    • oblique lines \(r=\frac{ab}{b\cos\theta+a\sin\theta}\) (or use a standard form such as \(\frac{x}{a}+\frac{y}{b}=1,\) \(y=mx+b,\) or \(Ax+By=C\) and convert using \(x=r\cos\theta\) and \(y=r\sin\theta\)).

Homework

Complete these for Monday, February 26. Show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Convert the following rectangular equations of lines to polar equations.
    1. \(y=\frac{1}{2}x\)
    2. \(2x+3y=6\)
    3. \(y=-3x+5\)
    4. \(y=-x\)
    5. \(\frac{x}{4}+\frac{y}{-3}=1\)
  2. Convert the following polar equations of lines to rectangular equations. Find the slope and any intercepts.
    1. \(\theta = 45^\circ\)
    2. \(r=2\sec\theta\)
    3. \(r=-3\csc\theta\)
    4. \(r=\frac{4}{3\cos\theta+2\sin\theta}\)
